Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Robust Trajectory Based Analysis for Stochastic Hybrid Systems Abstraction and Verification

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Hybrid systems (deterministic and stochastic) are widely used as the mathematical framework to model many engineering systems and natural phenomena, ranging from biomolecular processes to modern air traffic control systems. One of the most important analysis problems in hybrid systems is reachability/safety analysis, where the question of interest is whether the system can enter an undesirable state during its execution. For stochastic hybrid systems, the same question is asked with a probabilistic qualifier, i.e., what is the probability of the occurrence of such an event. This question is crucial in analyzing the performance or correctness of engineering systems, and the accuracy of the mathematical models of natural phenomena, such as cellular biomolecular processes.

This project develops formal analysis methods for reachability/safety analysis based on the execution trajectories of stochastic hybrid systems or their abstraction. The main tool used in this research is the notion of trajectory robustness, which is established using bisimulation functions. This technique offers a number of advantages over other methods, including simplicity of implementation, better complexity, easiness of parallel implementation, and possibility of partial verification. The project also aims to extend the analysis from static reachability/safety properties to dynamic ones that are specified by temporal logic.

The research program includes the development of necessary theoretical results, algorithms, and software tools for the application of the theory of trajectory based analysis. The integration of the theoretical results in a software tool will play an important role in disseminating the research output in the industry and academia. There are also ongoing efforts in applying the results in cutting edge engineering challenges, such as microscale actuation using bacteria and the development of portable UV-based water sterilizer.

In parallel with the research program, this project has an educational agenda involving K-12, undergraduate and graduate level education. The broader impact of the educational program is in educating new engineers and researchers that are fluent in multidisciplinary research collaborations and are aware of the tremendous potentials of such activities. The outreach component of the educational program will also improve pre-college students' awareness of the potential and attractiveness of engineering and research careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main challenge in system analysis for design and verification is system complexity. Analysis complexity increases when the state-space of the system is large (for example, if it involves a large number of subsystems) or when the dynamics of the system is complex (for example, non-linear vs. linear dynamics, stochastic vs. deterministic). In this project, we consider the analysis of system properties such as safety/reachability and correctness. In reachability/safety analysis, the question of interest is whether the system can enter an undesirable state during its execution. For stochastic hybrid systems, the same question is asked with a probabilistic qualifier, i.e., what is the probability of the occurrence of such event. System correctness is typically defined in terms of a specification, which is expressed in temporal logics.  The central question here is whether the system's execution trajectories satisfy the temporal logic specification.

Intellectual Merit: In this project, we developed formal system analysis methods based on the execution trajectories of hybrid systems. This technique offers some advantages over other methods, including simplicity of implementation, better complexity, and easiness of parallel implementation. Specific outcomes of the project are as follows.

  1. We developed the theory and software tool for trajectory-based safety/reachability analysis of hybrid systems.
  2. We developed the theory for trajectory-based abstraction of hybrid systems. This theory, in turn, enabled us to perform system analysis beyond safety/reachability and conformance to temporal logic specifications. For example, using this theory, we were able to prove fault diagnosability and design state observer.
  3. We developed algorithms for inferring temporal logic formulae based on observed trajectories of the system. These algorithms include a model discrimination algorithm in systems biology and a temporal logic inference algorithm for multi-agent systems.

Broader Impacts: Research outcomes from this project have been disseminated as peer-reviewed scientific publications, in addition to one book chapter and numerous seminars. This project partially supported 3 doctoral students and several undergraduate students during its execution. This project also supported STEM outreach initiatives to K-12 students, including Design Your Future Day for middle school girls and Engineering Ambassadors for high school and middle school students.
